Slow moving help (page 2)

  • Filters

Filters

The default filter for slow moving parts is ....-....-. This filter is a type of filter called a Regular Expression, also called regex for short.  You are more familiar with glob filtering.  Glob filtering primarily uses the astericks, *.  For example, 5010-0300-* will yield results like 5010-0300-000, 5010-0300-001, 5010-0300-003, 5010-0300-004, etc.  The equivalent using regex as a filter is "5010-0300-.*".  In this case, the dot (.) represents any charater, i.e. a, b, c, ..., z, 0, 1, 2, .... 9.  Here the dot, ., means any character, and the * means 0 or more of that 'any character'.

So then, if part nos. from a sw/sl BOM were 6415-2013-076 and 7302-0050-002, the ....-....-" filter would match numbers like 6415-2013-108, 6415-2013-118, 6415-2013-202, 7302-0050-000, 7302-0050-003, and 7302-0040-C from the sm BOM.  On the other hand, if any those 'any charaters' were replaced, then the filter is altered accordingly.  For example, 300.-01..- will match 3001-0100-001, 3005-0150-003, etc., and 3...-0050- will match 3001-0050-006 and 3214-0050-001-C.

Another usefull filter is .........., i.e 10 dots.  In this case, the first 10 characaters are, again, 'any character'. The equivalent, shortened filter is .{10}. This means, 'any charater' 10 times.  Both of these will match values like 9000-0006-000, 9263K297, A0013854-006, 3180-VMX05-000. And ....-.*- will match 9000-0006-000 and 3180-VMX05-000.

This is only the bare basics of regex filtering, and for use in bomcheck it should be all that is required. However if one wishes to delve into more complex examples, you can do a google search for "regex".
